title: Elegy at 18 – Analytical Questions (Band 5)
author: Aloma Davis
poem:
Elegy at 18
By Aloma Davis
If you take an object from a scale, it is lighter.
How, then, can an absence be so heavy?
Your loss is stony ballast dragging me under.
From now on I will shoulder a calendar of days
months, years, decades leaden with your loss.
Those who questioned you during your life
face a new grammatical challenge in your death;
how to describe you in the past tense.
I cannot do it yet. You are the epitome of the present continuous.
I am certain your pirate smile will still flash around the corner;
your velvet eyes meet mine. Denial shimmers on my road.
Aquaplaning through my days,
I refuse to see the crash I know is coming.
I have been so proud of you I can barely speak.
If only you could feel them; if my wings could enfold you safe.
Guilt fills me with demented rage that has no target but myself.
In the trail of your death, their silence is ear-splitting.
Their startled eyes slide away from mine and I see their mirage,
the way they swerve. It is their own past that makes them tense.
I know, soon, I must confess the outrageous truth.
I will correct myself and say what we have been swallowing:
“you were, you were.” But today, our fierce, sweet and clever one,
be present with us a moment more. Stay with me,
and let me love you for all that you are.

questions.question: What emotion is conveyed through the metaphor 'stony ballast dragging me under'?
The rhetorical question 'How, then, can an absence be so heavy?' highlights what central paradox?
options: That memory is easy to forget
That grief feels heavier than physical weight
questions.answer: That grief feels heavier than physical weight

questions.question: When Davis writes 'I will shoulder a calendar of days', what does 'calendar' symbolise?
options: A burden of time filled with loss
questions.answer: A burden of time filled with loss

questions.question: What does the poet suggest by calling the deceased 'the epitome of the present continuous'?
options: The poet has forgotten the loved one
The person lives only in the past
The speaker refuses to accept the finality of death
questions.answer: The speaker refuses to accept the finality of death

questions.question: The image 'your pirate smile will still flash around the corner' conveys which emotional stage of grief?
The phrase 'aquaplaning through my days' most likely symbolises:
options: A loss of control and avoidance of reality
questions.answer: A loss of control and avoidance of reality

questions.question: What does the oxymoron 'their silence is ear-splitting' reveal about social reactions to grief?
options: The speaker finds peace in quiet moments

questions.question: The repetition in 'you were, you were' best expresses:
options: A hesitant and painful acknowledgement of death
questions.answer: A hesitant and painful acknowledgement of death

questions.question: The use of grammatical language (e.g. 'past tense', 'present continuous') serves to:
options: Demonstrate the poet’s knowledge of linguistics
Add humour to the poem’s tone
Distance the poet from her emotions
Show how language mirrors emotional struggle
questions.answer: Show how language mirrors emotional struggle
